conclusion: Need to use the ideal gas law and properties of the gas at states A and B.
Initial state A: volume 1.0 × 10⁻³ m³, pressure 3.0 × 10⁵ Pa; Final state B: volume 2.0 × 10⁻³ m³, pressure 2.0 × 10⁵ Pa.
Use the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
Calculate number of moles n using initial and final states, n_B = n_A.
Substitute known values into the ideal gas law: 3 × 10^5 × 2 × 10^{-3} = n × 273 + n × 273.
Calculate temperature T at state B using ideal gas law: T_B = (6000 / 273) × 8.314 × 273 / (2 × 10^{-3}).
Compare calculated temperature at state B with initial temperature at state A.
Determine the final temperature at state B.
The temperature of the gas at state B is 300 K.
